C The m memory of Cy Cyrus is contemplated with pe
culiar complacency by most historians. His ge humanity &
love of justice distinguishes w him from ^ those other conquerors to
whom ambition was the ruling motive. Cy Cyrus was edu
cated in the strictest simplicity en early inured to fatigue
and ^ taught after the manners of the age, to consider glory as the
as the great and desirable bourne to which every virtu
ous man ought to direct his steps exertions . But the natural
mildness of his disposition led him the rather to seek for
honour in the pardon than in the punishment of his
enemies. and if he conquered it was to bestow a more and
his conquests ^ often appeared to f the fallen nations as in light
of a blessing rather than a curse. The romance with which
Xenophon has embellished the history of this prince and
the numerous ane anecdotes which he has either recor
invented in his honour renders as apparent by better
acquainted with the character of this monarch than of
any other of ancient times. Inmemorable anecdotes are
recorded of his virtue and mildness by his his Xenophon
but unfortunately this history must be looked upon regarded rather
as a romance than the real biography of the man; for al
through tradition might probably preserve several of the
private actions of so distinguished a man prince it e is
not probable that in ea yet the minuteness & egularity
